facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1956 filed.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment and decree dated September 23, 1952 in First Appeal No. 57 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 23, 1952, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 57 of 1949.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 13, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-The appellant and the Second respondent are both descendants

facts.text: Appellant and second respondent are descendants of Vallabhacharyaji who flourished more than 400 years ago.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the Second respondent are both descendants of Vallabhacharyaji, a great Vaishnava teacher who flourished more than 400 years ago.

facts.text: Shrine established at Nadiad more than 100 years ago.

anchor.surface_text: One such shrine was established more than 100 years ago at Nadiad and about the year 1899 A. D. a descendant of Vallabhacharyaji

facts.text: Anniruddhalalji Murlidharji became head of Nadiad shrine around 1899 by adoption.

anchor.surface_text: a descendant of Vallabhacharyaji who on adoption took the name of Anniruddhalalji Murlidharji became the head of the Nadiad shrine and was thus possessed

facts.text: Anniruddhalalji became head of Moti Haveli at Jamnagar in 1913 by adoption, took name Annirudhalalji Brijeshji.

anchor.surface_text: This gentleman also became by, adoption head of another shrine known as the Moti Haveli at Jamnagar in the year 1913 and then took a slightly different

facts.text: Both adoptions in accordance with Goda Dattak custom.

anchor.surface_text: name Annirudhalalji Brijeshji. Both these adoptions were in accordance with the Goda Dattak custom of adoption which prevailed among the members

facts.text: Aniruddhalalji died on December 17, 1935 leaving widow Mahalakshmi Bahuji Maharaj, first respondent.

facts.text: Suit brought by appellant challenging validity of adoption of second respondent.

arguments.claim: Rule in Dattaka Mimansa against Viruddha Sambandha putra is only recommendatory and not mandatory

anchor.surface_text: We have however held in Mrs. Abhiraj Kuer v. Debendra Singh 1  in which judgment has been delivered to-day that this rule in Dattaka Mimansa against Viruddha Sambandha putra is only recommendatory and not mandatory.

holdings.text: There is no custom barring the adoption of the wife's sister's husband in Goda Dattak form.

anchor.surface_text: On the materials on the record we are also satisfied that there is no custom barring the adoption of the wife, is sisters husband in Goda Dattak form.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof from texts, experts, or instances; Dattaka Mimansa rule against Viruddha Sambandha putra is recommendatory; even orthodox Dattak does not bar wife's sister's husband.

holdings.text: There is no custom in Goda Dattak adoptions requiring the adoptee to be from the family of the adoptive father if possible.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff has not been able to establish by either any authoritative texts or from the opinion of some person well learned about the Goda Dattaka customs that a custom exists barring the adoption of members from other Vallabhacharya families if it were possible to adopt members from the adoptive fathers family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff's evidence insufficient; no support from experts or texts; counter-instances provided by defendant; objects of Goda adoption satisfiable from other families.

holdings.text: No implied prohibition by Anniruddhalalji of adoption of anybody other than the plaintiff or his sons has been proved.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court is right in its conclusion that no implied prohibition by Anniruddhalalji of adoption of anybody other than the plaintiff or his sons has been proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter Ex.115 shows preference and authority to adopt, not exclusivity; oral evidence uncorroborated and unreliable; no direct prohibition stated.

holdings.text: Anniruddhalalji authorised the widow to make an adoption after his death.

anchor.surface_text: the letter Ex. 115 and the evidence of the plaintiffs own witnesses justify the conclusion that in his life time Anniruddhalalji authorised Mahalakshmi Bahuji Maharaj to make an adoption after his death

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter Ex.115 and plaintiff's witnesses confirm authority; mere preference for specific boy does not limit to him only.

holdings.text: Adoption valid despite absence of husband's sapindas' consent under Madras School of Mitakshara as there was authority from the husband.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there was authority from the husband to adopt and so even if the rule of Orthodox Dattak adoption was applicable and Anniruddhalalji was governed by the Madras School of Mitakshara the question of any consent of husbands sapindas does not arise at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Husband's authority (express/implied via Ex.115) dispenses with sapindas consent requirement under Madras Mitakshara or Orthodox Dattak.

holdings.text: The rule in Dattaka Mimansa against adoption of Viruddha Sambandha putra is only recommendatory and not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: We have however held in Mrs. Abhiraj Kuer v. Debendra Singh 1  in which judgment has been delivered to-day that this rule in Dattaka Mimansa against Viruddha Sambandha putra is only recommendatory and not mandatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following concurrent judgment in Mrs. Abhiraj Kuer v. Debendra Singh.

holdings.text: Whether section 14 Hindu Succession Act renders appeal infructuous left undecided.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this position we are of opinion that it would not proper for us to decide in the present case whether under section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act Defendant No. 1 had become the full owner of the properties in suit if the adoption by her was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Properties may be Devattar; separate suit pending; decide on merits and leave s.14 claim open.

holdings.text: Even if limitations of orthodox Dattak apply to Goda adoption, no bar to adoption of wife's sister's husband.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that it is difficult to see how the wifes sisters husband can be considered to be ViruddhaSambandha-putra. It is thus clear that even if the limitations of the orthodox Dattak adoption apply to Goda adoption there is no bar to the adoption of, the wifes sisters husband.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wife's sister's husband not Viruddha Sambandha putra; rule recommendatory anyway.

outcome.relief_summary: Validity of adoption of second respondent upheld; all three grounds challenging adoption rejected; no custom proved barring adoption of wife's sister's husband or requiring adoptee from adoptive father's family; no implied prohibition by deceased; sapindas consent not required due to husband's authority to widow to adopt.
directions: Section 14 Hindu Succession Act claim left open for 1st respondent if adoption held invalid (though not so held).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there was authority from the husband to adopt and so even if the rule of Orthodox Dattak adoption was applicable and Anniruddhalalji was governed by the Madras School of Mitakshara the question of any consent of husbands sapindas does not arise at all.
